title: What is the typical cost of a business plan for a small company? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’ve only written about 255 business plans so I may not be as qualified as some others. When someone tells you they are going to write you a plan for $799, you are getting a 7–11 plan, with gas pumps (without is $599) written overseas, modified to suit your business. So you may have a child care business, but the cost of a Twinkie may still accidentally show up in your plan. To do a decent job, I estimate one hour per page of text (~350 words) plus 2 to 4 hours per page of financials, depending upon the business model. I do a lot of subscription business work, so I know how long this will take. At $60 to $70/hr. plus research time, you can figure $2600 to $4000 for most custom written plans. There’s always the 7–11 plan for those looking for useless but cheap. BTW - Some guy advertised on Craigslist the other day he needed a restaurant plan in New York City but would only pay $300 for the plan. So he’s going to spend $200,000 to maybe $750,000 or more to build a restaurant and he’s only capable of paying $300. I wonder what he’s planning to use that plan for?

I've written business plans for a range of businesses, including an organic grocer looking to expand, a construction company apartment project, a medical device start up, a veterinary medical imaging center, etc  The time required to write a business plan varies widely with the type of business, the industry, and the purpose of the plan (raising initial capital, special projects, restructuring, etc).  The first thing a business plan writer is going to want to do before quoting you a price is to estimate the time required to research the industry, market, competition, and do the actual writing ( it's 80% research/ 20% writing).  However, it is impossible to do so given the limited information in your original question.  If you would like, you can PM me with more details and I should be able to give you a ball-park range.

The only cost one should have is printing and binding of copies of it. as it should only be written bey the principal. Having someone write it for you is creating some distance, however small, between what is in your head and what lands on the page. As a business consultant, if someone tells me that it was written for them, I have immediate pause. You need to be “all in” from the start.

To get a better answer, you should indicate why you need a business plan.  Is this for a loan? investors? etc?   A formal business plan prepared by a 3rd party is mostly unnecessary these days except in certain situations.

I'd offer you free business plan software available at Invest Engine: http://www.investengine.com/tour_free_business_plan_software.php With it you can evaluate what consultants have prepared or even write professionl business plan yourself
